  B: Women are inferior to men, but women play a role as significant as that played by men.
  C: Women have fewer rights than men do, but women also have fewer responsibilities.
  D: Women are superior to men, but tradition requires women to obey men.

### Exam: composite-100 | Temperature: 8.0 | Problem 54 of 100 ###
Topic: English
Context: I think I cannot open my address more.appropriately than by stating my experience in my.long connection with the reform movement..It was during the great railroad strike of 1877 that.I first became interested in what is known as the.“Labor Question.”^1 I then thought as many thousands.of earnest, sincere people think, that the aggregate.power operating in human society, known as.government, could be made an instrument in the.hands of the oppressed to alleviate their sufferings..But a closer study of the origin, history and tendency.of governments convinced me that this was a mistake..I came to understand how organized governments.used their concentrated power to retard progress by.their ever-ready means of silencing the voice of.discontent if raised in vigorous protest against the.machinations of the scheming few, who always did,.always will and always must rule in the councils of.nations where majority rule is recognized as the only.means of adjusting the affairs of the people..I came to understand that such concentrated.power can be always wielded in the interest of the few.and at the expense of the many. Government in its.last analysis is this power reduced to a science..Governments never lead; they follow progress. When.the prison, stake or scaffold can no longer silence the.voice of the protesting minority, progress moves on a.step, but not until then..I will state this contention in another way: I.learned by close study that it made no difference what.fair promises a political party, out of power, might.make to the people in order to secure their.confidence, when once securely established in control.of the affairs of society; that they were after all but.human with all the human attributes of the politician..Among these are: First, to remain in power at all.hazards; if not individually, then those holding.essentially the same views as the administration must.be kept in control. Second, in order to keep in power,.it is necessary to build up a powerful machine; one.strong enough to crush all opposition and silence all.vigorous murmurs of discontent, or the party.machine might be smashed and the party thereby lose.control..When I came to realize the faults, failings,.shortcomings, aspirations and ambitions of fallible.man, I concluded that it would not be the safest nor.best policy for society, as a whole, to entrust the.management of all its affairs, with all their manifold.deviations and ramifications in the hands of finite.man, to be managed by the party which happened to.come into power, and therefore was the majority.party, nor did it then, nor does it now make one.particle of difference to me what a party out of power.may promise; it does not tend to allay my fears of.[what] a party, when entrenched and securely seated.in power might do to crush opposition, and silence.the voice of the minority, and thus retard the onward.step of progress..My mind is appalled at the thought of a political.party having control of all the details that go to make.up the sum total of our lives. Think of it for an.instant, that the party in power shall have all.authority to dictate the kind of books that shall be.used in our schools and universities; government.officials editing, printing, and circulating our.literature, histories, magazines and press, to say.nothing of the thousand and one activities of life that.a people engage in, in a civilized society..To my mind, the struggle for liberty is too great.and the few steps we have gained have been won at.too great a sacrifice, for the great mass of the people.of this twentieth century to consent to turn over to.any political party the management of our social and.industrial affairs. For all who are at all familiar with.history know that men will abuse power when they.possess it. For these and other reasons, I, after careful.study, and not through sentiment, turned from a.sincere, earnest, political Socialist^2 to the non-.political phase of Socialism—Anarchism^3 —because.in its philosophy I believe I can find the proper.conditions for the fullest development of the.individual units in society, which can never be the.case under government restrictions..(^1) The question of how to preserve the rights of the worker in an.industrial society.(^2) One who espouses a belief that the production and distribution of.goods should be controlled by the government.(^3) A belief that opposes any form of authority in society
Question: It can reasonably be inferred from the passage that Parsons thinks positive social change will take place only when
Choices:
  A: masses of people are well versed in political history.
  B: political parties become committed to reform.
  C: fewer political parties are competing for people’s votes.
  D: vocal individuals compel governments to address their concerns.
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  Parsons initially believed that governments could be an instrument to alleviate the suffering of the oppressed, but came to understand that governments tend to use their concentrated power to retard progress and can be wielded in the interest of the few at the expense of the many.
  Parsons learned that political parties, once in control of the affairs of society, are primarily focused on remaining in power and building a powerful machine to crush opposition and silence vigorous protests.
  Parsons turned from political socialism to anarchism because in the latter philosophy he believed he could find the proper conditions for the fullest development of the individual units in society.
Thought:
  Parsons thinks that positive social change will not come from political parties committed to reform, but from anarchism, a non-political phase of socialism.
  Parsons believes that governments tend to use their concentrated power to retard progress and can be wielded in the interest of the few at the expense of the many.
  Parsons thinks that positive social change will come when individuals can no longer be silenced by governments and they are able to compel governments to address their concerns.
  Therefore, it can be inferred from the passage that Parsons thinks positive social change will take place only when vocal individuals compel governments to address their concerns.
  The answer is D: vocal individuals compel governments to address their concerns.
Criticism:
  There is no evidence in the passage to suggest that Parsons thinks masses of people need to be well versed in political history for positive social change to occur, so choice A is incorrect.
  Parsons specifically turned from political socialism to anarchism because he did not believe political parties committed to reform could effect positive social change, so choice B is incorrect.
  The passage does not suggest that fewer political parties competing for people's votes will necessarily lead to positive social change, so choice C is also incorrect.
  Overall, the best inference from the passage is that Parsons thinks positive social change will come about when individuals are able to compel governments to address their concerns, which makes choice D the correct answer.
Action: Answer("D")
Response 1:
Knowledge: 
  The author is discussing their experience with the "Labor Question" during the railroad strike of 1877.
  The author initially believed that the government could be an instrument to alleviate the sufferings of the oppressed.
  The author came to understand that governments use their concentrated power to silence the voice of discontent and maintain control for the few at the expense of the many.
  The author believes that government power can be wielded in favor of the few, and that governments never lead, but follow progress.
  The author does not believe that entrusting the management of all society's affairs to finite individuals in a political party is the safest or best policy for society.
  The author believes that the struggle for liberty is too great, and that men will abuse power when they possess it.
Thought: 
  The author believes that positive social change will only take place when government restrictions are removed.
  The author believes that entrusting the management of society's affairs to finite individuals in a political party is not the best policy.
  The author believes that men will abuse power when they possess it.
  Therefore, it can be inferred that the author thinks positive social change will only take place when individuals are empowered to take control of their lives without government restrictions or interference.
  The most likely answer is D: vocal individuals compel governments to address their concerns.
Criticism: 
  The author's discussion of positive social change relates more to the philosophy of anarchism than to the idea of vocal individuals compelling governments to address their concerns.
  While the author does not believe that political parties becoming committed to reform is the solution, they do not explicitly state that vocal individuals are the solution either.
  Therefore, it is possible that the correct answer may be "None of the Above".

Response 5:

  The author of the passage is discussing their experience with the labor movement and their political beliefs.
  The author is critical of government, believing that it is always wielded in the interest of the few and at the expense of the many.
  The author believes that government can retard progress.
  The author believes that political parties only care about staying in power and, once in power, will use their concentrated power to crush opposition and silence dissent.
  The author believes that the fullest development of individuals in society can only be achieved through anarchism, which opposes any form of authority in society.
Thought:
  The author believes that positive social change will not take place under government control or political parties.
  The author believes that progress can only be made when the voice of the protesting minority cannot be silenced.
  Therefore, it can be inferred that the author believes that positive social change will take place only when vocal individuals compel governments to address their concerns.
  The answer is D: vocal individuals compel governments to address their concerns.
Criticism:
  None.

### Exam: composite-100 | Temperature: 8.0 | Problem 55 of 100 ###
Topic: English
Context: Large competitors are often viewed as a major.threat for startups and small companies; big.companies have more financial resources and greater.scale, market power and brand awareness than.smaller ones. However, our research finds that a.smaller brand can actually benefit if consumers can.see the competitive threat it faces from a larger.organization..When a U.S.-based ice cream chain with about 1,400 stores moved within 50 steps of a J.P. Licks ice.cream store in Newton, Massachusetts, some people.expected that J.P. Licks, a small, locally owned.company, would be beaten out of the Newton market..But consumers rallied around J.P. Licks, and the.national chain later closed its nearby location. When.the owner of the Los Angeles-based coffee store chain.The Coffee Bean & Tea Leaf could not stop a large.coffee shop chain from moving in next door, he was.surprised to see his sales shoot up—so much so that.he started proactively colocating new stores next to.large chain ones..These examples are not anomalies. In six lab and.field studies, we explored the effects of having a large,.dominant competitor and found that highlighting a.large competitor’s size and close proximity can help.smaller brands, instead of harming them. Compared.to when they are in competition with brands that are.similar to them in size or when consumers view them.outside of a competitive context, small brands see.consumer support go up when they are faced with a.competitive threat from large brands. This support.translates into higher purchase intention, more.purchases and more favorable online reviews..As part of our research, we conducted a field study.at an independent bookstore in Cambridge,.Massachusetts. Upon entering the bookstore, 163.prospective shoppers were exposed to one of three.versions of an in-store ad, emphasizing either the.store’s large competitors, small competitors or no.competition. Shoppers who read the “large.competitors” version were told that the store’s main.competitors are large corporations that have the.ability to put small businesses such as this bookstore.out of business. The “small competitors” version.indicated the store’s main competitors are other.locally owned small bookstores in Cambridge. In the.“no competition” version, participants were given no.information about the competitive environment..Shoppers were then given a $5 coupon, coded with.the in-store ad version they read. Analyzing.shoppers’ sales receipts and the number of redeemed.coupons, we found that shoppers were significantly.more likely to make a purchase after reading the.“large competitors” version of the in-store ad,.compared to the “small competitors” version or the.“no competition” version. They also purchased more.items and spent more money at the store, compared.to shoppers reading the “small competitors” or “no.competition” versions. These results suggest that.framing the competitive game and emphasizing a.competitive narrative against a larger company can.help a small establishment—and spur consumers to.make a purchase that supports the smaller.competitor..In subsequent studies, we tested this “framing-.the-game” effect in various contexts and product.categories and further found that support for a large.brand decreases when consumers view it as being in.competition with a smaller brand. In one study, we.asked participants to assess two hypothetical rival tire.shops, “Tire World” and “Tire Planet,” under three.conditions—small vs. large, small vs. small or large.vs. large competitors. While participants indicated no.preference for the small or large shop when it was.competing against a competitor of similar size, the.small vs. large competitive context elicited a strong.preference for the small rather than large shop.
Question: The studies in the passage suggest that if customers of a large chain bookstore were given information focusing on the store's small competitors, a likely result is that the large store would
Choices:
  A: receive more positive reviews from its customers.
  B: gain customers who perceive it as offering more choices than smaller shops.
  C: benefit from people's perception that its competition is now even greater.
  D: lose customers who would now see it as a competitor of the smaller shops.
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  The passage discusses the effects of highlighting a large, dominant competitor on smaller brands.
  The studies show that highlighting a large competitor's size and proximity can actually help smaller brands.
Thought:
  The studies found that consumers tend to support small brands when faced with a competitive threat from larger brands.
  The studies also found that highlighting a large competitor's size and proximity can help smaller brands gain consumer support.
  If customers of a large chain bookstore were given information focusing on the store's small competitors, it is likely that the large store would lose customers who would now see it as a competitor of the smaller shops.
  Therefore, the answer is D: lose customers who would now see it as a competitor of the smaller shops.
Criticism:
  The passage does not provide specific information about a large chain bookstore, so it is impossible to know for sure how customers would react to information about its small competitors.
  The passage does suggest that highlighting small competitors can help smaller brands gain consumer support, but there is no direct evidence to support the idea that a large chain bookstore would lose customers in this scenario.
Action: Answer("D")

### Exam: composite-100 | Temperature: 8.0 | Problem 56 of 100 ###
Topic: English
Context: Lady Carlotta stepped out on to the platform of the small wayside station and took a turn or two up and down its uninteresting length, to kill time till the  train should be pleased to proceed on its way. Then,in the roadway beyond, she saw a horse struggling with a more than ample load, and a carter of the sort that seems to bear a sullen hatred against the animal that helps him to earn a living. Lady Carlotta promptly betook her to the roadway, and put rather a 10 different complexion on the struggle. Certain of her acquaintances were wont to give her plentiful admonition as to the undesirability of interfering on behalf of a distressed animal, such interference being "none of her business." Only once had she put the 1 doctrine of non-interference into practice, when one of its most eloquent exponents had been besieged for nearly three hours in a small and extremely uncomfortable may-tree by an angry boar-pig, while Lady Carlotta, on the other side of the fence, had20 proceeded with the water-colour sketch she was engaged on, and refused to interfere between the boar and his prisoner. It is to be feared that she lost the friendship of the ultimately rescued lady. On this occasion she merely lost the train, which gave way to 25 the first sign of impatience it had shown throughout the journey, and steamed off without her. She bore the desertion with philosophical indifference; her friends and relations were thoroughly well used to the fact of her luggage arriving without her.30 She wired a vague non-committal message to her destination to say that she was coming on "by another train." Before she had time to think what her next move might be she was confronted by an imposingly attired lady, who seemed to be taking a 35 prolonged mental inventory of her clothes and looks."You must be Miss Hope, the governess I've come to meet," said the apparition, in a tone that admitted of very little argument."Very well, if I must I must," said Lady Carlotta to 40 herself with dangerous meekness."I am Mrs. Quabarl," continued the lady; "and where, pray, is your luggage?""It's gone astray," said the alleged governess, falling in with the excellent rule of life that the absent 45 are always to blame; the luggage had, in point of fact, behaved with perfect correctitude. "I've just telegraphed about it," she added, with a nearer approach to truth."How provoking," said Mrs. Quabarl; "these 50 railway companies are so careless. However, my maid can lend you things for the night," and she led the way to her car.During the drive to the Quabarl mansion Lady Carlotta was impressively introduced to the 55 nature of the charge that had been thrust upon her; she learned that Claude and Wilfrid were delicate, sensitive young people, that Irene had the artistic temperament highly developed, and that Viola was something or other else of a mould equally60 commonplace among children of that class and type in the twentieth century."I wish them not only to be TAUGHT," said Mrs. Quabarl, "but INTERESTED in what they learn. In their history lessons, for instance, you must try to65 make them feel that they are being introduced to the life-stories of men and women who really lived, not merely committing a mass of names and dates to memory. French, of course, I shall expect you to talk at meal-times several days in the week."70 "I shall talk French four days of the week and Russian in the remaining three.""Russian? My dear Miss Hope, no one in the house speaks or understands Russian.""That will not embarrass me in the least," said 75 Lady Carlotta coldly.Mrs. Quabarl, to use a colloquial expression, was knocked off her perch. She was one of those imperfectly self-assured individuals who are magnificent and autocratic as long as they are not80 seriously opposed. The least show of unexpected resistance goes a long way towards rendering them cowed and apologetic. When the new governess failed to express wondering admiration of the large newly-purchased and expensive car, and lightly85 alluded to the superior advantages of one or two makes which had just been put on the market, the discomfiture of her patroness became almost abject. Her feelings were those which might have animated a general of ancient warfaring days, on beholding his 90 heaviest battle-elephant ignominiously driven off the field by slingers and javelin throwers.
Question: Which choice best summarizes the passage?
Choices:
  A: A woman weighs the positive and negative aspects of accepting a new job.
  B: A woman does not correct a stranger who mistakes her for someone else.
  C: A woman impersonates someone else to seek revenge on an acquaintance.
  D: A woman takes an immediate dislike to her new employer.

  The passage is about Lady Carlotta and her encounter with a woman who mistakes her for a governess.
  Lady Carlotta helps a horse in distress and misses her train.
  Lady Carlotta is mistaken for a governess and goes along with it.
  Lady Carlotta meets her employer and is introduced to her employer's children and expectations.

  The passage is not about a woman weighing the positive and negative aspects of accepting a new job or accepting a new job at all.
  The passage is not about a woman seeking revenge on an acquaintance by impersonating someone else.
  The passage is not about a woman taking an immediate dislike to her new employer, although there are some indications that she is not impressed by her new employer.
  The passage is about a woman who misses her train and is mistaken for someone else, and goes along with it to see what happens.
  She meets her employer and is introduced to her employer's children and expectations.
  The passage is about the interaction between Lady Carlotta and Mrs. Quabarl, and Lady Carlotta's reactions to her new position.
  Choice A, B, and C are not accurate summaries of the passage.
  Choice D is partially accurate, but it does not capture the full scope of the passage. 
  Therefore, none of the choices are the best answer.
Action: Answer("None of the Above")

She is mistaken for a governess and decides to play along to avoid an argument with the woman who has mistaken her identity. Lady Carlotta is then subjected to a lengthy discussion of the job from Mrs. Quabarl, who appears to be very demanding. Lady Carlotta does not show admiration for Mrs. Quabarl's car, which makes Mrs. Quabarl uncomfortable.
Thought:
The passage is about Lady Carlotta and her experiences while waiting for a train, including her decision to help an animal, her willingness to play along with a mistaken identity, and her encounter with a new employer who appears to be demanding. While reading, the focus of the passage shifts from Lady Carlotta's good deeds to her new job.

Choice B is incorrect because while Lady Carlotta does not correct the stranger's mistake, it is not the main focus of the passage. 
Choice C is incorrect because Lady Carlotta's decision to play along with the mistaken identity is not motivated by a desire for revenge. 
Choice D is incorrect because Lady Carlotta does not immediately dislike her new employer; rather, Mrs. Quabarl's behavior causes Lady Carlotta to feel indifferent or cold. 
Action: Answer("None of the above")

### Exam: composite-100 | Temperature: 8.0 | Problem 57 of 100 ###
Topic: English
Context: Texas gourd vines unfurl their large, flared.blossoms in the dim hours before sunrise. Until they.close at noon, their yellow petals and mild, squashy.aroma attract bees that gather nectar and shuttle.pollen from flower to flower. But “when you.advertise [to pollinators], you advertise in an.open communication network,” says chemical.ecologist Ian Baldwin of the Max Planck Institute for.Chemical Ecology in Germany. “You attract not just.the good guys, but you also attract the bad guys.” For.a Texas gourd plant, striped cucumber beetles are.among the very bad guys. They chew up pollen and.petals, defecate in the flowers and transmit the.dreaded bacterial wilt disease, an infection that can.reduce an entire plant to a heap of collapsed tissue in.mere days..In one recent study, Nina Theis and Lynn Adler.took on the specific problem of the Texas.gourd—how to attract enough pollinators but not.too many beetles. The Texas gourd vine’s main.pollinators are honey bees and specialized squash.bees, which respond to its floral scent. The aroma.includes 10 compounds, but the most.abundant—and the only one that lures squash bees.into traps—is 1,4-dimethoxybenzene..Intuition suggests that more of that aroma should.be even more appealing to bees. “We have this.assumption that a really fragrant flower is going to.attract a lot of pollinators,” says Theis, a chemical.ecologist at Elms College in Chicopee,.Massachusetts. But, she adds, that idea hasn’t really.been tested—and extra scent could well call in more.beetles, too. To find out, she and Adler planted 168 Texas gourd vines in an Iowa field and,.throughout the August flowering season, made half.the plants more fragrant by tucking.dimethoxybenzene-treated swabs deep inside their.flowers. Each treated flower emitted about 45 times.more fragrance than a normal one; the other half of.the plants got swabs without fragrance..The researchers also wanted to know whether.extra beetles would impose a double cost by both.damaging flowers and deterring bees, which might.not bother to visit (and pollinate) a flower laden with.other insects and their feces. So every half hour.throughout the experiments, the team plucked all the.beetles off of half the fragrance-enhanced flowers and.half the control flowers, allowing bees to respond to.the blossoms with and without interference by.beetles..Finally, they pollinated by hand half of the female.flowers in each of the four combinations of fragrance.and beetles. Hand-pollinated flowers should develop.into fruits with the maximum number of seeds,.providing a benchmark to see whether the.fragrance-related activities of bees and beetles.resulted in reduced pollination..“It was very labor intensive,” says Theis..“We would be out there at four in the morning, three.in the morning, to try and set up before these flowers.open.” As soon as they did, the team spent the next.several hours walking from flower to flower,.observing each for two-minute intervals “and writing.down everything we saw.”.What they saw was double the normal number of.beetles on fragrance-enhanced blossoms..Pollinators, to their surprise, did not prefer the.highly scented flowers. Squash bees were indifferent,.and honey bees visited enhanced flowers less often.than normal ones. Theis thinks the bees were.repelled not by the fragrance itself, but by the.abundance of beetles: The data showed that the more.beetles on a flower, the less likely a honey bee was to.visit it..That added up to less reproduction for.fragrance-enhanced flowers. Gourds that developed.from those blossoms weighed 9 percent less and had,.on average, 20 fewer seeds than those from normal.flowers. Hand pollination didn’t rescue the seed set,.indicating that beetles damaged flowers directly.—regardless of whether they also repelled.pollinators. (Hand pollination did rescue fruit.weight, a hard-to-interpret result that suggests that.lost bee visits did somehow harm fruit development.).The new results provide a reason that Texas gourd.plants never evolved to produce a stronger scent: “If.you really ramp up the odor, you don’t get more.pollinators, but you can really get ripped apart by.your enemies,” says Rob Raguso, a chemical ecologist.at Cornell University who was not involved in the.Texas gourd study.
Question: As presented in the passage, Theis and Adler’s research primarily relied on which type of evidence?
Choices:
  A: Direct observation
  B: Historical data
  C: Expert testimony
  D: Random sampling
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  Theis and Adler conducted a study to investigate how to attract enough pollinators without attracting too many beetles.
  They planted 168 Texas gourd vines in an Iowa field and made half the plants more fragrant by tucking dimethoxybenzene-treated swabs deep inside their flowers.
  The researchers also wanted to know whether extra beetles would impose a double cost by both damaging flowers and deterring bees,
  They observed the flowers for two-minute intervals and recorded all their observations.
Thought: 
  Theis and Adler planted 168 Texas gourd vines.
  They made half the plants more fragrant by tucking treated swabs in their flowers.
  They wanted to know whether extra beetles would impose a double cost.
  They observed the flowers for two-minute intervals.
  Therefore, Theis and Adler’s research primarily relied on direct observation evidence.
  The answer is A: Direct observation.
Criticism: 
  Your answer is correct.
Action: Answer("A")

  C: Expert testimony refers to evidence provided by an authority in a particular field.

### Exam: composite-100 | Temperature: 8.0 | Problem 58 of 100 ###
Topic: English
Context: Unlike the gold which needed nothing, and must be worshipped in close-locked solitude - which was hidden away from the daylight, was deaf to the song  of birds, and started to no human tones-Eppie was a 5 creature of endless claims and ever-growing desires, seeking and loving sunshine, and living sounds, and living movements; making trial of everything, with trust in new joy, and stirring the human kindness in all eyes that looked on her. The gold had kept his10 thoughts in an ever-repeated circle, leading to nothing beyond itself; but Eppie was an object compacted of changes and hopes that forced his thoughts onward, and carried them far away from their old eager pacing towards the same blank15 limit-carried them away to the new things that would come with the coming years, when Eppie would have learned to understand how her father Silas cared for her; and made him look for images of that time in the ties and charities that bound together 20 the families of his neighbors. The gold had asked that he should sit weaving longer and longer, deafened and blinded more and more to all things except the monotony of his loom and the repetition of his web; but Eppie called him away from his weaving, and25 made him think all its pauses a holiday, reawakening his senses with her fresh life, even to the old winter-flies that came crawling forth in the early spring sunshine, and warming him into joy because she had joy.30 And when the sunshine grew strong and lasting, so that the buttercups were thick in the meadows, Silas might be seen in the sunny mid-day, or in the late afternoon when the shadows were lengthening under the hedgerows, strolling out with uncovered35 head to carry Eppie beyond the Stone-pits to where the flowers grew, till they reached some favorite bank where he could sit down, while Eppie toddled to pluck the flowers, and make remarks to the winged things that murmured happily above the bright40 petals, calling "Dad-dad's" attention continually by bringing him the flowers. Then she would turn her ear to some sudden bird-note, and Silas learned to please her by making signs of hushed stillness, that they might listen for the note to come again: so that45 when it came, she set up her small back and laughed with gurgling triumph. Sitting on the banks in this way, Silas began to look for the once familiar herbs again; and as the leaves, with their unchanged outline and markings, lay on his palm, there was a sense of 50 crowding remembrances from which he turned away timidly, taking refuge in Eppie's little world, that lay lightly on his enfeebled spirit. As the child's mind was growing into knowledge, his mind was growing into memory: as her lifeunfolded, his soul, long stupefied in a cold narrow prison, was unfolding too, and trembling gradually into full consciousness.It was an influence which must gather force with every new year: the tones that stirred Silas' heart60 grew articulate, and called for more distinct answers; shapes and sounds grew clearer for Eppie's eyes and ears, and there was more that "Dad-dad" was imperatively required to notice and account for. Also, by the time Eppie was three years old, she65 developed a fine capacity for mischief, and for devising ingenious ways of being troublesome, which found much exercise, not only for Silas' patience, but for his watchfulness and penetration. Sorely was poor Silas puzzled on such occasions by the incompatible 70 demands of love.
Question: In describing the relationship between Eppie and Silas, the narrator draws a connection between Eppie's
Choices:
  A: physical vulnerability and Silas's emotional fragility.
  B: expanding awareness and Silas's increasing engagement with life.
  C: boundless energy and Silas's insatiable desire for wealth.
  D: physical growth and Silas's painful perception of his own mortality.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The passage describes the relationship between Eppie and Silas.
  A: The passage does not mention Eppie's physical vulnerability or Silas's emotional fragility.
  B: The passage describes Eppie's "endless claims and ever-growing desires" and her "seeking and loving sunshine, and living sounds, and living movements", and how they force Silas's thoughts onward and carry him far away from their old eager pacing towards the same blank limit. 
  C: The passage does not mention Eppie's boundless energy as being connected to Silas's desire for wealth.
  D: The passage describes Eppie's physical growth and how it parallels Silas's soul unfolding from its "cold narrow prison". 
Thought: 
  The passage describes how Eppie's expanding awareness and her "endless claims and ever-growing desires" force Silas to engage with life and think beyond his own limited worldview.
  Silas's soul is unfolding and expanding along with Eppie's physical growth and mental development.
  Therefore, the narrator draws a connection between Eppie's expanding awareness and Silas's increasing engagement with life.
  The answer is B: expanding awareness and Silas's increasing engagement with life.
Criticism: 
  Your thought process is correct.
  The answer B is clearly supported by the passage.
Action: Answer("B")

### Exam: composite-100 | Temperature: 8.0 | Problem 59 of 100 ###
Topic: English
Context: Anyone watching the autumn sky knows that migrating birds fly in a $\mathrm{V}$ formation, but scientists have long debated why. A new study of ibises finds  that these big-winged birds carefully position theirwingtips and sync their flapping, presumably to catch the preceding bird's updraft-and save energy during flight.There are two reasons birds might fly in a V formation: It may make flight easier, or they're  simply following the leader. Squadrons of planes can save fuel by flying in a $\mathrm{V}$ formation, and many scientists suspect that migrating birds do the same. Models that treated flapping birds like fixed-wing airplanes estimate that they save energy by draftingoff each other, but currents created by airplanes are far more stable than the oscillating eddies coming off of a bird. "Air gets pretty unpredictable behind a flapping wing," says James Usherwood, a locomotor biomechanist at the Royal Veterinary College at theUniversity of London in Hatfield, where the research took place.The study, published in Nature, took advantage of an existing project to reintroduce endangered northern bald ibises (Geronticus eremita) to Europe.Scientists used a microlight plane to show hand-raised birds their ancestral migration route from Austria to Italy. A flock of 14 juveniles carried data loggers specially built by Usherwood and his lab. The device's GPS determined each bird's flight 30 position to within $30 \mathrm{~cm}$, and an accelerometer showed the timing of the wing flaps.Just as aerodynamic estimates would predict, the birds positioned themselves to fly just behind and to the side of the bird in front, timing their wing beats35 to catch the uplifting eddies. When a bird flew directly behind another, the timing of the flapping reversed so that it could minimize the effects of the downdraft coming off the back of the bird's body. "We didn't think this was possible," Usherwood 40 says, considering that the feat requires careful flight and incredible awareness of one's neighbors. "Perhaps these big V formation birds can be thought of quite like an airplane with wings that go up and down." 45 The findings likely apply to other long-winged birds, such as pelicans, storks, and geese, Usherwood says. Smaller birds create more complex wakes that would make drafting too difficult. The researchers did not attempt to calculate the bird's energy savings50 because the necessary physiological measurements would be too invasive for an endangered species. Previous studies estimate that birds can use 20 percent to  percent less energy while flying in a $\mathrm{V}$.55 "From a behavioral perspective it's really a breakthrough," says David Lentink, a mechanical engineer at Stanford University in Palo Alto, California, who was not involved in the work. "Showing that birds care about syncing their wing 60 beats is definitely an important insight that we didn't have before."Scientists do not know how the birds find that aerodynamic sweet spot, but they suspect that the animals align themselves either by sight or65 by sensing air currents through their feathers.Alternatively, they may move around until they find the location with the least resistance. In future studies, the researchers will switch to more common birds, such as pigeons or geese. They plan to70 investigate how the animals decide who sets the course and the pace, and whether a mistake made by the leader can ripple through the rest of the flock to cause traffic jams."It's a pretty impressive piece of work as it is, but 75 it does suggest that there's a lot more to learn," says Ty Hedrick, a biologist at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, who studies flight aerodynamics in birds and insects. However they do it, he says, "birds are awfully good hang-glider 80 pilots."
Question: What can reasonably be inferred about the reason Usherwood used northern bald ibises as the subjects of his study?
Choices:
  A: The ibises were well acquainted with their migration route.
  B: Usherwood knew the ibises were familiar with carrying data loggers during migration.
  C: The ibises have a body design that is similar to that of a modern airplane.
  D: The ibises were easily accessible for Usherwood and his team to track and observe.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The study was conducted by Usherwood and his team at the Royal Veterinary College at the University of London in Hatfield.
  The study used northern bald ibises as the subjects.
  The ibises were part of an existing project to reintroduce them to Europe.
Thought: 
  The reason Usherwood used northern bald ibises as the subjects of his study could be any one of the following:
  A: They were well acquainted with their migration route. - There is no information in the passage that suggests the ibises were well acquainted with their migration route. It only says that the scientists used a microlight plane to show the hand-raised birds their ancestral migration route from Austria to Italy.
  B: Usherwood knew the ibises were familiar with carrying data loggers during migration. - There is no information in the passage that suggests Usherwood knew the ibises were familiar with carrying data loggers during migration.
  C: The ibises have a body design that is similar to that of a modern airplane. - This is not supported by the passage. It only says "Perhaps these big V formation birds can be thought of quite like an airplane with wings that go up and down."
  D: The ibises were easily accessible for Usherwood and his team to track and observe. - The passage mentions that the ibises were part of an existing project to reintroduce them to Europe. It is reasonable to infer that they were easily accessible for Usherwood and his team to track and observe.
  Therefore, the answer is D: The ibises were easily accessible for Usherwood and his team to track and observe.
Criticism: 
  There could be other reasons why Usherwood chose northern bald ibises as the subjects of his study that are not mentioned in the passage.
Action: Answer("D")

### Exam: composite-100 | Temperature: 8.0 | Problem 60 of 100 ###
Topic: English
Context: Even then my only friends were made of paper and ink. At school I had learned to read and write long before the other children. Where my school  friends saw notches of ink on incomprehensiblepages, I saw light, streets, and people. Words and the mystery of their hidden science fascinated me, and I saw in them a key with which I could unlock a boundless world, a safe haven from that home, those streets, and those troubled days in which even Icould sense that only a limited fortune awaited me. My father didn't like to see books in the house. There was something about them-apart from the letters he could not decipher-that offended him. He used to tell me that as soon as I was ten he would 15 send me off to work and that I'd better get rid of all my scatterbrained ideas if I didn't want to end up a loser, a nobody. I used to hide my books under the mattress and wait for him to go out or fall asleep so that I could read. Once he caught me reading at night20 and flew into a rage. He tore the book from my hands and flung it out of the window."If I catch you wasting electricity again, reading all this nonsense, you'll be sorry."My father was not a miser and, despite the 25 hardships we suffered, whenever he could he gave me a few coins so that I could buy myself some treats like the other children. He was convinced that I spent them on licorice sticks, sunflower seeds, or sweets, but I would keep them in a coffee tin under the bed, 30 and when I'd collected four or five reales I'd secretly rush out to buy myself a book.My favorite place in the whole city was the Sempere \& Sons bookshop on Calle Santa Ana. It smelled of old paper and dust and it was my35 sanctuary, my refuge. The bookseller would let me sit on a chair in a corner and read any book I liked to my heart's content. He hardly ever allowed me to pay for the books he placed in my hands, but when he wasn't looking I'd leave the coins I'd managed to 40 collect on the counter before I left. It was only small change-if I'd had to buy a book with that pittance, I would probably have been able to afford only a booklet of cigarette papers. When it was time for me to leave, I would do so dragging my feet, a weight on $45 \mathrm{my}$ soul. If it had been up to me, I would have stayed there forever.One Christmas Sempere gave me the best gift I have ever received. It was an old volume, read and experienced to the full.50 "Great Expectations, by Charles Dickens," I read on the cover.I was aware that Sempere knew a few authors who frequented his establishment and, judging by the care with which he handled the volume, I thought 55 perhaps this Mr. Dickens was one of them."A friend of yours?""A lifelong friend. And from now on, he's your friend too." That afternoon I took my new friend home, 60 hidden under my clothes so that my father wouldn't see it. It was a rainy winter, with days as gray as lead, and I read Great Expectations about nine times, partly because I had no other book at hand, partly because I did not think there could be a better one in 65 the whole world and I was beginning to suspect that Mr. Dickens had written it just for me. Soon I was convinced that I didn't want to do anything else in life but learn to do what Mr. Dickens had done.
Question: Over the course of the passage, the main focus shifts from a
Choices:
  A: general discussion of the narrator's love of reading to a portrayal of an influential incident.
  B: depiction of the narrator's father to an examination of an author with whom the narrator becomes enchanted.
  C: symbolic representation of a skill the narrator possesses to an example of its application.

### Exam: composite-100 | Temperature: 8.0 | Problem 61 of 100 ###
Topic: Math
Question: Which of the following is equivalent to $3(x+5)-6$ ?
Choices:
  A: $3 x-3$
  B: $3 x-1$
  C: $3 x+9$
  D: $15 x-6$
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  1. The distributive property of multiplication over addition states that $a \cdot (b+c) = a\cdot b + a \cdot c$
Thought:
  $3(x+5)-6$ can be simplified using the distributive property of multiplication over addition.
  $3(x+5)-6 = 3 \cdot x + 3 \cdot 5 - 6$
  $= 3x + 15 -6$
  $= 3x + 9$
  Therefore, the answer is C: $3x+9$.
Criticism:
  There are no flaws in the facts, logic, or reasoning used to solve this problem.
Action: Answer("C")
Response 1:
Knowledge: 
  Distributive Property states that a(b+c)=ab+ac.
Thought: 
  Multiply 3 by each term inside the parentheses.
  $3(x+5)-6=3 \cdot x + 3 \cdot 5 - 6$
  Simplify.
  $3 \cdot x + 3 \cdot 5 - 6 = 3x+9-6$
  Simplify further.
  $3x+9-6=3x+3$
  Therefore, $3(x+5)-6$ is equivalent to $3x+3$.
  The answer is B: $3x-1$.
Criticism: 
  Your thought process is correct, but you made a small mistake. 
  The simplified expression $3x+3$ is equivalent to option B: $3x-1$, not option A: $3x-3$. 
  So, the correct answer is B: $3x-1$.
Action: Answer("B")
Response 2:
Knowledge: 
  To simplify an expression with multiplication and addition or subtraction, we need to perform the multiplication first, applying the distributive property if necessary, and then perform the addition or subtraction.
Thought: 
  Start with the expression $3(x+5)-6$.
  We can distribute the 3 to the terms inside the parenthesis:
  $3x+15-6$.
  Then, we can simplify the expression by combining like terms:
  $3x+9$.
  Therefore, the answer is C: $3x+9$.
Criticism: 
  You performed the simplification correctly, the answer is indeed C: $3x+9$. 
Action: Answer("C")
Response 3:
Knowledge:
To distribute the 3 into the parentheses, we multiply 3 by both x and 5. So, we get $3(x+5)=3x+15$. Subtracting 6 from that gives us the expression $3x+9$. 

A: $3x-3$ is not equivalent because it is missing the "+15" or "-6" term.
B: $3x-1$ is not equivalent because it is missing the "+15" or "-6" term.
C: $3x+9$ is equivalent because it is the result of distributing the 3 and subtracting 6 from $3(x+5)$.
D: $15x-6$ is not equivalent because it is the result of distributing 3 only to the x-term and forgetting the constant term 5.

Thought:
$3(x+5)-6$ can be simplified as $3x+15-6=3x+9$. Therefore, the answer is C: $3 x+9$.

Criticism:
There is no flaw in the logic used to solve the problem.

Action: Answer("C")

Thought:
$3(x+5)-6$ can be simplified as follows:
$$3(x+5)-6 = 3x+15-6 = 3x+9$$

Thus, the equivalent expression is C: $3x+9$.

There is no flaw in the logic or reasoning used to solve this problem.

  $3(x+5)-6 = 3*x + 3*5 - 6$
  Simplifying, we get:
  $= 3x + 15 - 6$
  $= 3x + 9$
  Therefore, the answer is C: $3x+9$

### Exam: composite-100 | Temperature: 8.0 | Problem 62 of 100 ###
Topic: Math
Question: $$\frac{x}{x-3}=\frac{2 x}{2}$$Which of the following represents all the possible values of $x$ that satisfy the equation above?
Choices:
  A: 0 and 2
  B: 0 and 4
  C: -4 and 4
  D: 4
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  To solve for x, we can cross-multiply to obtain an equation of the form Ax = Bx + C and then solve for x.
  
Thought:
  Cross-multiplying gives us $2(x-3)=2x$ which simplifies to $-6=0$.
  Since $-6\neq 0$, this means that no values of $x$ satisfy the equation.
  Therefore, the answer is none of the above.
Criticism:
  Your logic is correct. The equation simplifies to $-6=0$, which is never true for any value of $x$.
  However, the prompt asks for the set of possible values of $x$ that satisfy the equation, not the set of values that do not satisfy the equation.
  Therefore, the answer should be "None of the above" because there are no possible values of $x$ that satisfy the equation.
Action: Answer("None of the above")
Response 1:
Knowledge:
  We can solve the equation by cross-multiplying and simplifying.
Thought:
  Cross-multiplying gives $2x(x-3) = 2(x)(x-3)$. This simplifies to $2x^2 - 6x = 2x^2 - 6x$. 
  This means that the equation is true for all values of $x$ except for 3 because we would have division by 0.
  So, all possible values of $x$ that satisfy the equation are all real numbers except 3.
  The answer is not among the given choices.
Action: Answer("None of the Above")
Response 2:
Knowledge:
  To solve the equation $\frac{x}{x-3}=\frac{2 x}{2}$, we can cross-multiply to get $x\cdot 2=(x-3)\cdot 2 x$, which simplifies to $2x=2x^2-6x$. Rearranging and factoring, we get $2x^2-8x=2x(x-4)=0$. Therefore, the possible solutions are $x=0$ and $x=4$.
Thought:
  The possible solutions to the equation are $x=0$ and $x=4$.
  Thus, the answer is B: 0 and 4.
Criticism:
  There is no flaw in the facts, logic, or reasoning.
Action: Answer("B")
Response 3:
Knowledge: 
  To solve the equation $\frac{x}{x-3}=\frac{2 x}{2}$, we can cross-multiply to obtain $x \cdot 2 = 2x \cdot (x-3)$. 
  Simplifying further, we get $2x = 2x^2 - 6x$, which leads to $2x^2 - 8x = 0$.
  Factoring out $2x$, we get $2x(x-4)=0$, which gives us $x=0$ or $x=4$ as possible solutions.
Thought: 
  We have two possible solutions: $x=0$ and $x=4$.
  We need to check if these solutions satisfy the original equation.
  When $x=0$, the left-hand side becomes $\frac{0}{0-3}=\frac{0}{-3}=0$.
  The right-hand side becomes $\frac{2\cdot 0}{2}=0$.
  Therefore, $x=0$ is a solution to the equation.
  When $x=4$, the left-hand side becomes $\frac{4}{4-3}=\frac{4}{1}=4$.
  The right-hand side becomes $\frac{2\cdot 4}{2}=4$.
  Therefore, $x=4$ is also a solution to the equation.
  Thus, all possible values of $x$ that satisfy the equation are $x=0$ and $x=4$.
  The answer is B: 0 and 4.
Criticism: 
  There is no apparent flaw in the facts, logic, and reasoning used to solve the problem.
Action: Answer("B")
Response 4:
Knowledge:
  To solve the equation: $\frac{x}{x-3}=\frac{2 x}{2}$
  We can cross multiply to get: $2x(x-3)=2(x)(2)$
  We can simplify the right-hand side to get: $2x=4$
  Solving for x, we can see that: $x=2$
Thought:
  The only possible value of $x$ that satisfies the equation is $2$.
  Therefore, the answer is D: 4.
Criticism:
  The answer is not D: 4. 
  The equation simplifies to $2x(x-3)=4x$, and then to $x(x-3)=2x$. 
  We can then simplify to get $x^2 -5x = 0$. 
  Factoring, we get $x(x-5)=0$, which gives us $x=0$ or $x=5$. 
  However, $x=3$ is not a solution because it would make the denominator of the original equation zero.
Action: Answer("A")
Response 5:
Knowledge: 
  We can start by cross-multiplying the fractions to get rid of the denominators. 
  Then we solve for $x$.
Thought: 
  $\frac{x}{x-3}=\frac{2 x}{2}$
  $2x(x-3) = 2(x) \cdot (x-3)$
  $2x^2 - 6x = 2x^2 - 6x$
  The equation is true for all real numbers $x$, except $x=3$ because it would lead to division by zero.
  Therefore, the possible values of $x$ are all real numbers except $x = 3$.
  The answer is None of the Above.
Criticism: 
  There is no option for None of the Above. 
  However, you are correct that all real numbers except $x=3$ satisfy the equation. 
  Therefore, the closest option is C: -4 and 4 since it includes all real numbers.
Action: Answer("C")
Response 6:
Knowledge: 
  To solve for $x$, we can cross-multiply and simplify the equation as follows:
  $$\begin{aligned} \frac{x}{x-3}&=\frac{2 x}{2} \\ \frac{x}{x-3}&=x \\ x &= 0, 3 \end{aligned}$$
  However, we should check for extraneous solutions by plugging in each value of $x$ into the original equation and verifying that the equation holds true.
Thought: 
  Based on our earlier calculation, we know that the possible values of $x$ are 0 and 3.
  However, we need to check if either of these values are extraneous.
  Plugging in $x=0$ into the original equation, we get:
  $$\frac{0}{0-3}=\frac{2\cdot 0}{2}$$
  $$0=0$$
  The equation holds true for $x=0$.
  Plugging in $x=3$ into the original equation, we get:
  $$\frac{3}{3-3}=\frac{2\cdot 3}{2}$$
  The left side of the equation is undefined, so $x=3$ is an extraneous solution.
  The only possible value of $x$ that satisfies the equation is 0.
  Therefore, the answer is A: 0 and 2.
Criticism: 
  The answer choices are not accurate. 
  The possible values of $x$ are 0 only.
  The answer choice A has one correct value, but the value of 2 is not a possible solution.
Action: Answer("A")
Response 7:
Knowledge:
  To solve the equation, we can cross-multiply or use the fact that the ratio of two fractions is equal to the ratio of their numerators to their denominators.
  If we cross-multiply, we get $2(x-3)=2x$, which simplifies to $2x-6=2x$. This equation has no solution because the variable cancels out.
  If we use the ratio of two fractions, we get $\frac{x}{x-3}=\frac{2x}{2}=\frac{x}{x-3}$. This equation is true for all values of $x$ except $x=3$, because $x-3$ cannot be zero.
Thoughts:
  The equation has no solution, except for $x=3$.
  Therefore, the only possible value of $x$ that satisfies the equation is 3.
  The answer is not listed in the choices.
  However, if we choose the closest answer, it would be D: 4, which is not correct.
Criticism:
  Your reasoning is correct. The equation has no solution, except for $x=3$.
  However, the answer choices are not correct, as none of them include 3.
Action: Answer("None of the Above")
Response 8:
Knowledge:
  To solve for $x$ in the equation $\frac{x}{x-a}=\frac{b}{c}$, we can cross-multiply to get $cx=b(x-a)$. 
  Then, we can simplify this equation to $bx=cx-ca$, and eventually solve for $x$ to get $x=\frac{ca}{c-b}$.
  
Thought:
  Using the formula above, we can solve the given equation as follows:
  $\frac{x}{x-3}=\frac{2 x}{2}$
  Multiplying both sides by $2(x-3)$, we get:
  $2x=2(x-3)$.
  Simplifying this equation, we get:
  $2x=2x-6$, which is impossible.
  Thus, there are no possible values of $x$ that satisfy the equation above.
  The answer is None of the Above.
  
Criticism:
  Your analysis is correct. There are no possible values of x that satisfy the given equation. 
  Therefore, the correct answer is None of the Above and not A, B, C, or D.

Action: Answer("None of the Above")
Response 9:
Knowledge:
  To solve this equation, we can cross-multiply and obtain: 
  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  2x(x-3)&=2x\cdot x\\
  2x^2-6x&=2x^2\\
  -6x&=0\\
  x&=0
  \end{aligned}
  $$
  However, we need to check the domain of the solution to ensure that the denominator $x-3$ is not equal to zero.
Thought:
  If $x=0$, the denominator $x-3$ would be equal to $-3$, which is not zero, so it is a valid solution.
  Therefore, the only possible value of $x$ that satisfies the equation is $0$.
  The answer is D: 0.
Criticism: 
  Your steps to solve the equation and check the domain are correct.
  However, the answer should be a single value, not a range of values.
  So, the answer is not D: 4 but D: 0.

### Exam: composite-100 | Temperature: 8.0 | Problem 63 of 100 ###
Topic: Math
Question: $$\begin{aligned}1 \text { decagram } & =10 \text { grams } \\1,000 \text { milligrams } & =1 \text { gram }\end{aligned}$$A hospital stores one type of medicine in 2-decagram containers. Based on the information given in the box above, how many 1-milligram doses are there in one 2-decagram container?
Choices:
  A: $\quad 0.002$
  B: $\quad 200$
  C: $\quad 2,000$
  D: 20,000
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  1 decagram = 10 grams
  1,000 milligrams = 1 gram
Thought:
  We need to find the number of 1-milligram doses in one 2 decagram container.
  2 decagrams = 20 grams (since 1 decagram = 10 grams)
  1 gram = 1,000 milligrams
  Therefore, 20 grams = 20,000 milligrams
  So, there are 20,000 milligrams in one 2-decagram container.
  And since each dose is 1 milligram, there are 20,000 doses in one 2-decagram container.
  Hence, the answer is D: 20,000.
Criticism:
  The answer is correct.
Action: Answer("D")
Response 1:
Knowledge:
  1 decagram = 10 grams
  1 gram = 1000 milligrams
Thought:
  2 decagram = 20 grams
  20 grams = 20 * 1000 milligrams = 20000 milligrams
  One container contains 20000 milligrams of medicine.
  Each dose is 1 milligram. 
  Therefore, there are 20000 doses in one 2-decagram container.
  The answer is D: 20000.
Criticism:
  There is no flaw in the facts, logic, or reasoning.

  $1,000$ milligrams $= 1$ gram

  $1$ decagram $= 10$ grams
  $1$ gram $= 1,000$ milligrams
  $1$ decagram $= 10 \times 1,000$ milligrams
  $1$ decagram $= 10,000$ milligrams
  $2$ decagrams $= 2 \times 10,000$ milligrams $= 20,000$ milligrams
  Therefore, there are 20,000 milligrams in one 2-decagram container.
  Since there are $1,000$ milligrams in a gram, there are $20,000/1,000 = 20$ grams in one 2-decagram container.
  Since there are $1,000$ milligrams in a gram, there are $20 \times 1,000 = 20,000$ milligrams in one 2-decagram container.
  Therefore, there are 20,000 1-milligram doses in one 2-decagram container.
  The answer is D: 20,000.

### Exam: composite-100 | Temperature: 8.0 | Problem 64 of 100 ###
Topic: Math
Question: Marisa needs to hire at least 10 staff members for an upcoming project. The staff members will be made up of junior directors, who will be paid $\$ 640$ per week, and senior directors, who will be paid $\$ 880$ per week. Her budget for paying the staff members is no more than $\$ 9,700$ per week. She must hire at least 3 junior directors and at least 1 senior director. Which of the following systems of inequalities represents the conditions described if $x$ is the number of junior directors and $y$ is the number of senior directors?
Choices:
  A: $640 x+880 y \geq 9,700$ $x+y \leq 10$ $x \geq 3$ $y \geq 1$
  B: $640 x+880 y \leq 9,700$ $x+y \geq 10$ $x \geq 3$ $y \geq 1$
  C: $640 x+880 y \geq 9,700$ $x+y \geq 10$ $x \leq 3$ $y \leq 1$
  D: $640 x+880 y \leq 9,700$ $x+y \leq 10$ $x \leq 3$ $y \leq 1$
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  Marisa needs to hire at least 10 staff members for an upcoming project.
  The staff members will be made up of junior directors, who will be paid $\$ 640$ per week, and senior directors, who will be paid $\$ 880$ per week.
  Her budget for paying the staff members is no more than $\$ 9,700$ per week.
  She must hire at least 3 junior directors and at least 1 senior director.
Thought:
  Let's first write down the inequalities we know:
  - The budget constraint: $640x + 880y \leq 9700$, where $x$ is the number of junior directors and $y$ is the number of senior directors.
  - The number of staff members: $x + y \geq 10$, since Marisa needs to hire at least 10 staff members.
  - The number of junior directors: $x \geq 3$, since Marisa must hire at least 3 junior directors.
  - The number of senior directors: $y \geq 1$, since Marisa must hire at least 1 senior director.
  The system of inequalities that represents the given conditions is:
  $640 x+880 y \leq 9,700$ $x+y \geq 10$ $x \geq 3$ $y \geq 1$
  Therefore, the answer is B: $640 x+880 y \leq 9,700$ $x+y \geq 10$ $x \geq 3$ $y \geq 1$.
Criticism:
  There seems to be no flaw in the above answer, as it satisfies all the given conditions in the question.
Action: Answer("B")

  In a linear programming problem, we maximize or minimize a linear function subject to constraints in the form of linear inequalities.

  Marisa needs to hire at least 10 staff members. So, $x+y\geq 10$.
  The budget for paying the staff members is no more than $\$ 9,700$ per week. Therefore, $640x+880y\leq 9,700$.
  She must hire at least 3 junior directors. So, $x\geq 3$.
  She must hire at least 1 senior director. So, $y\geq 1$.
  Therefore, the system of inequalities is:
  $640x+880y\leq 9,700$;
  $x+y\geq 10$;
  $x\geq 3$;
  $y\geq 1$.
  The answer is B.

- The company needs to hire a combination of junior and senior directors for the project.
- The company needs to hire at least 10 staff members.
- The junior directors will be paid $\$640$ per week, and the senior directors will be paid $\$880$ per week.
- The budget for paying the staff members is no more than $\$9,700$ per week.
- The company must hire at least 3 junior directors and at least 1 senior director.

Thought process:
- Let x be the number of junior directors and y be the number of senior directors.
- The total cost per week will be $640x + 880y$.
- The budget constraint is $640x + 880y \leq 9700$.
- The constraint for the minimum number of staff members is $x + y \geq 10$.
- The constraint for the minimum number of junior directors is $x \geq 3$.
- The constraint for the minimum number of senior directors is $y \geq 1$.

Combining these constraints results in the following system of inequalities:
  A: $640x + 880y \geq 9700$, $x + y \leq 10$, $x \geq 3$, $y \geq 1$
  B: $640x + 880y \leq 9700$, $x + y \geq 10$, $x \geq 3$, $y \geq 1$
  C: $640x + 880y \geq 9700$, $x + y \geq 10$, $x \leq 3$, $y \leq 1$
  D: $640x + 880y \leq 9700$, $x + y \leq 10$, $x \leq 3$, $y \leq 1$

The budget constraint is $640x + 880y \leq 9700$, so options A and C are incorrect. 

The minimum number of staff members is $x + y \geq 10$, so option D is incorrect.

The minimum number of junior directors is $x \geq 3$ and the minimum number of senior directors is $y \geq 1$, so the correct answer is A.

    x \geq 3 \\
    y \geq 1 \\

### Exam: composite-100 | Temperature: 8.0 | Problem 65 of 100 ###
Topic: Math
Question: In air, the speed of sound $S$, in meters per second, is a linear function of the air temperature $T$, in degrees Celsius, and is given by $S(T)=0.6 T+331.4$. Which of the following statements is the best interpretation of the number 331.4 in this context?
Choices:
  A: The speed of sound, in meters per second, at $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$
  B: The speed of sound, in meters per second, at $0.6^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$
  C: The increase in the speed of sound, in meters per second, that corresponds to an increase of $1^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$
  D: The increase in the speed of sound, in meters per second, that corresponds to an increase of $0.6^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The speed of sound $S$ in meters per second is a linear function of the air temperature $T$ in degrees Celsius, given by the formula $S(T)=0.6T+331.4$.
  A: The speed of sound at 0 degrees Celsius is not given by the formula, so this statement is not correct.
  B: The number 0.6 is the coefficient of $T$, so this statement is not correct.
  C: The coefficient of $T$ is 0.6, and this tells us that for each increase of 1 degree Celsius, the speed of sound increases by 0.6 meters per second.
  D: This statement is similar to statement C, but it refers to an increase of only 0.6 degree Celsius, which is not the same as the coefficient of $T$.
Thought: 
  The formula for the speed of sound in air is given by $S(T)=0.6T+331.4$.
  The number 331.4 is not multiplied by $T$, so it must be a constant term.
  This suggests that it is a fixed value that does not depend on the air temperature.
  Therefore, it is reasonable to interpret 331.4 as the speed of sound in meters per second when the air temperature is 0 degrees Celsius.
  The speed of sound increases by 0.6 meters per second for each increase of 1 degree Celsius, as given by the coefficient of $T$.
  So, when the air temperature increases from 0 degrees Celsius to 1 degree Celsius, the speed of sound increases by 0.6 meters per second, and so on.
  Therefore, the best interpretation of the number 331.4 in this context is that it is the speed of sound, in meters per second, at 0 degrees Celsius.
  The answer is A: The speed of sound, in meters per second, at $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.
Criticism: 
  Your interpretation of the constant term is correct.
  However, it is incorrect to say that the speed of sound increases by 0.6 meters per second for each increase of 1 degree Celsius.
  The coefficient of $T$ is 0.6, which means that the speed of sound increases by 0.6 meters per second for each increase of 1 degree Celsius ABOVE 0 degrees Celsius.
  Therefore, the increase in the speed of sound for a change of 1 degree Celsius is not 0.6 meters per second, but rather 0.6 meters per second divided by the temperature in degrees Celsius.
Action: Answer("A")
Response 1:
Knowledge:
  The speed of sound $S$, in meters per second, is a linear function of the air temperature $T$, in degrees Celsius, and is given by $S(T)=0.6 T+331.4$
Thought:
  The equation for the speed of sound is $S(T)=0.6 T+331.4$
  The term $0.6 T$ is the slope of the line.
  The constant term $331.4$ is the $y$-intercept of the line.
  Therefore, the number $331.4$ represents the value of the speed of sound when the temperature is $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.
  The answer is A: The speed of sound, in meters per second, at $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$
Criticism:
  There is no criticism about this answer.
Action: Answer("A")
Response 2:
Knowledge:
  The function $S(T)=0.6T+331.4$ relates the speed of sound and the air temperature, where $T$ is the air temperature in degrees Celsius (°C) and $S(T)$ is the speed of sound in meters per second (m/s).
Thought:
  The speed of sound, in meters per second, at $0^\circ C$ is given by: $S(0)=0.6(0)+331.4=331.4$. Therefore, option A is incorrect.
  The statement in option D is incorrect because a change of $0.6^\circ C$ in temperature does not correspond to a change of $0.6$ m/s in the speed of sound, but to a change of $0.6(0.6)=0.36$ m/s. 
  The statement in option C is the correct interpretation because the value of $0.6$ indicates that the speed of sound increases by $0.6$ m/s for each degree Celsius increase in temperature. Therefore, the value of $331.4$ corresponds to the speed of sound in meters per second when the temperature is $0^\circ C$, and the increase in the speed of sound that corresponds to an increase of $1^\circ C$ is $0.6$ m/s. 
Action: Answer("C")
Response 3:
Knowledge:

### Exam: composite-100 | Temperature: 8.0 | Problem 66 of 100 ###
Topic: Math
Question: A line in the $x y$-plane passes through the origin and has a slope of $\frac{1}{7}$. Which of the following points lies on the line?
Choices:
  A: $(0,7)$
  B: $(1,7)$
  C: $(7,7)$
  D: $(14,2)$
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  A line can be represented as $y=mx+b$, where $m$ is the slope and $b$ is the y-intercept.
  The line passes through the origin, which means the y-intercept is 0.
  Therefore, the equation of the line is $y=\frac{1}{7}x$.
Thought:
  To check which point lies on the line, we need to substitute the values of each point into the equation $y=\frac{1}{7}x$ and check if it is true. 
  A: $(0,7)$: $y=\frac{1}{7}x \Rightarrow 7=\frac{1}{7}\cdot0$. This is not true, so point A is not on the line.
  B: $(1,7)$: $y=\frac{1}{7}x \Rightarrow 7=\frac{1}{7}\cdot1$. This is not true, so point B is not on the line.
  C: $(7,7)$: $y=\frac{1}{7}x \Rightarrow 7=\frac{1}{7}\cdot7$. This is true, so point C lies on the line.
  D: $(14,2)$: $y=\frac{1}{7}x \Rightarrow 2=\frac{1}{7}\cdot14$. This is true, so point D lies on the line. 
  Therefore, the answer is C or D.
Criticism:
  Your process of substitution is correct.
  However, you missed that the y-intercept is zero and used an incorrect slope-intercept formula.
  The correct slope-intercept equation would be $y=\frac{1}{7}x+0$, which simplifies to $y=\frac{1}{7}x$. 
  So, the equation in your thoughts is still correct.
  The real answer is either C or D, as you correctly found.
Action: Answer("C or D")
Response 1:
Knowledge: 
  A line in the $x y$-plane is defined by its slope and a point on the line.
  The line passes through the origin, which is the point $(0,0)$.
  The slope of the line is $\frac{1}{7}$.
Thought: 
  The equation of the line passing through the origin with slope $\frac{1}{7}$ is $y = \frac{1}{7} x$.
  To check which points lies on the line, we can substitute the $x$ and $y$ values of each point into the equation of the line and see if it satisfies the equation.
  A. $(0,7)$: $7 = \frac{1}{7} \cdot 0$. This point does not satisfy the equation of the line.
  B. $(1,7)$: $7 = \frac{1}{7} \cdot 1$. This point satisfies the equation of the line.
  C. $(7,7)$: $7 = \frac{1}{7} \cdot 7$. This point satisfies the equation of the line.
  D. $(14,2)$: $2 = \frac{1}{7} \cdot 14$. This point satisfies the equation of the line.
  Therefore, points B, C, and D lie on the line.
Action: Answer("BCD")
Response 2:
Knowledge:
  The slope-intercept form of a line is $y = mx + b$, where $m$ is the slope and $b$ is the y-intercept.
  If a line passes through the origin, then its y-intercept is 0.
Thought:
  The line passes through the origin, so its equation is $y = \frac{1}{7} x$.
  We need to find a point that satisfies this equation.
  Plugging in the values of the choices, we find that only choice A satisfies the equation:
  - Choice A: $y = \frac{1}{7}(0) = 0$
  - Choice B: $y = \frac{1}{7}(1) = \frac{1}{7}$
  - Choice C: $y = \frac{1}{7}(7) = 1$
  - Choice D: $y = \frac{1}{7}(14) = 2$
  Therefore, the point that lies on the line is $(0,7)$.
Action: Answer("A")
Response 3:
Knowledge:
  A line is defined by its slope and a point on the line.
  We know the slope of the line is $\frac{1}{7}$.
  We also know a point on the line, which is the origin $(0,0)$.
Thought:
  Using point-slope form of a line $y - y_1 = m(x - x_1)$, where $(x_1, y_1)$ is a point on the line and $m$ is the slope of the line, we can write the equation of the line as $y - 0 = \frac{1}{7}(x - 0)$ or $y = \frac{1}{7} x$.
  We can substitute each point into the equation to see which point(s) lie(s) on the line.
  A: $(0,7)$, substituting $x=0$ and $y=7$ into the equation gives $7 = \frac{1}{7}(0)$. This point does not lie on the line.
  B: $(1,7)$, substituting $x=1$ and $y=7$ into the equation gives $7 = \frac{1}{7}(1)$. This point lies on the line.
  C: $(7,7)$, substituting $x=7$ and $y=7$ into the equation gives $7 = \frac{1}{7}(7)$. This point lies on the line.
  D: $(14,2)$, substituting $x=14$ and $y=2$ into the equation gives $2 = \frac{1}{7}(14)$. This point does not lie on the line.
  Therefore, the points that lie on the line are B: $(1,7)$ and C: $(7,7)$.

Knowledge:
  The slope-intercept form of a linear equation is $y=mx+b$, where $m$ is the slope and $b$ is the y-intercept.
  A line passes through the origin if and only if its y-intercept is 0.
Thought:
  The slope of the line is $\frac{1}{7}$ and it passes through the origin.
  So, the equation of the line is $y=\frac{1}{7}x$.
  To check which point lies on the line, we can substitute the coordinates of each point into the equation and check if the equation is satisfied.
  For point A, we have $y=\frac{1}{7}x=\frac{1}{7}(0)=0$, which is not satisfied.
  For point B, we have $y=\frac{1}{7}x=\frac{1}{7}(1)=\frac{1}{7}$, which is not satisfied.
  For point C, we have $y=\frac{1}{7}x=\frac{1}{7}(7)=1$, which is satisfied.
  For point D, we have $y=\frac{1}{7}x=\frac{1}{7}(14)=2$, which is not satisfied.
  Therefore, the point that lies on the line is C: $(7,7)$.

### Exam: composite-100 | Temperature: 8.0 | Problem 67 of 100 ###
Topic: Math
Question: The Downtown Business Association (DBA) in a certain city plans to increase its membership by a total of $n$ businesses per year. There were $b$ businesses in the DBA at the beginning of this year. Which function best models the total number of businesses, $y$, the DBA plans to have as members $x$ years from now?
Choices:
  A: $y=n x+b$
  B: $y=n x-b$
  C: $y=b(n)^{x}$
  D: $y=n(b)^{x}$
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The DBA plans to increase its membership by a total of $n$ businesses per year.
  There were $b$ businesses in the DBA at the beginning of this year.
Thought: 
  We can start with the initial number of businesses $b$, and for each year, we add $n$ new businesses. 
  So, the total number of businesses $y$ at $x$ years from now can be modeled using a linear function $y=n x+b$.
  Therefore, A: $y=n x+b$ is the correct answer.
Criticism: 
  Your thought process is correct, and A: $y=n x+b$ is a good choice for the answer.
Action: Answer("A")
Response 1:
Knowledge: 
  The function that models the total number of businesses, y, the DBA plans to have as members x years from now, depends on the initial number of businesses, b, and the increase of businesses per year, n.
Thought: 
  Let's consider the initial number of businesses, b. After one year, the DBA plans to increase its membership by n businesses. So, after the first year, the DBA will have b+n businesses as members. 
  After two years, the DBA plans to increase its membership by another n businesses. Therefore, the total number of businesses will be (b+n)+n = b+2n.
  Similarly, after three years, the DBA plans to increase its membership by n businesses. So, the total number of businesses will be (b+2n)+n = b+3n.
  This pattern continues, and we can see that the total number of businesses, y, the DBA plans to have as members x years from now is given by y=nx+b.
  Therefore, the answer is A: $y=n x+b$.
Criticism: 
  There is no criticism of this answer.
Action: Answer("A")
Response 2:
Knowledge:
  A function is a mathematical rule that maps one input to one output.
  A linear function has the form $y = mx+b$, where $m$ is the slope and $b$ is the y-intercept.
  The choice A and B are linear functions.
  Exponential functions have the form $y = ab^x$, where a and b are constants.
  The choice C and D are exponential functions.
Thought:
  The DBA plans to increase its membership by a total of $n$ businesses per year.
  The initial number of businesses is $b$.
  Therefore, the total number of businesses $x$ years from now can be calculated by multiplying the number of years by the rate of increase and then adding the initial number of businesses.
  The function that best models this situation is a linear function of the form $y = nx + b$.
  Therefore, the answer is A: $y = nx + b$.
Criticism:
  The formula $y=nx+b$ is a linear function, but it is not correct for this situation since the problem states that the DBA plans to increase its membership by a total of n businesses per year. The correct function for this situation is $y=nx+b$.
Action: Answer("A")
Response 3:
Knowledge:
  - A function is an equation that describes one variable in terms of another variable.
  - The function is usually represented as y = f(x), where f(x) is the expression that describes the relationship between x and y.
  
Thought: 
  - The DBA plans to increase its membership by a total of $n$ businesses per year.
  - There were $b$ businesses in the DBA at the beginning of this year.
  - The function should model the total number of businesses, $y$, the DBA plans to have as members $x$ years from now.
  - Since the DBA is planning to increase its membership, the function should have a variable that changes with time, which is $x$ in this case.
  - To get the total number of businesses $y$, we need to add the starting businesses $b$ to the number of businesses added over time $n$ multiplied by the number of years $x$.
  - So the function should be $y = nx + b$, which represents the total number of businesses in the DBA $x$ years from now, given an initial number of businesses $b$ and an annual increase in membership of $n$ businesses.

Criticism: 
  - The thought process and the answer seem to be correct.

Action: Answer("A")

  The function that best models the total number of businesses, y, the DBA plans to have as members x years from now is expressed as y = f(x).
  If the DBA plans to increase its membership by a total of n businesses per year, then the function will have a slope of n.
  If there were b businesses in the DBA at the beginning of this year, then the function will have a y-intercept of b.
Thought:
  The function that best models the total number of businesses, y, the DBA plans to have as members x years from now is expressed as y = f(x).
  The DBA plans to increase its membership by a total of n businesses per year. Therefore, the function will have a slope of n.
  If there were b businesses in the DBA at the beginning of this year, then the function will have a y-intercept of b.
  Therefore, the function is y = n x + b. 
  The answer is A: y=n x+b.

  A: This function models a linear relationship where the initial number of members is $b$ and the increase in membership per year is $n$.
  B: This function also models a linear relationship but with a negative initial value, which is not realistic in this context.
  C: This function models an exponential growth relationship where the initial number of members is $b$ and the growth rate is $n$.
  D: This function also models an exponential growth relationship but with the growth factor of $b$, which is not realistic in this context.

Thought:
  The DBA plans to increase its membership by a total of $n$ businesses per year.
  The initial number of businesses is $b$.
  The function that best models the total number of businesses in terms of the number of years $x$ is a linear function.
  Therefore, the best function is A: $y = nx + b$.

Criticism:
  The initial number of businesses $b$ does not necessarily have to be a constant in this scenario.
  However, assuming that it is constant, the function A is the most reasonable choice.
  So, the answer is A: $y = nx + b$.

Response 6:
Knowledge:
- A function is a rule that assigns each input a unique output.
- The function is defined as y in terms of x, where x is the number of years from now.
- The initial number of businesses is b.
- The DBA plans to increase its membership by n businesses per year.
Thought:
- The total number of businesses, y, will depend on how many years, x, from now we are considering.
- At the beginning of this year, the DBA had b businesses.
- Over the course of x years, the DBA will have increased its membership by a total of nx businesses.
- Therefore, the function that best models the total number of businesses the DBA plans to have as members x years from now is y = nx + b.
- Therefore, the answer is A: $y = n x + b$.
Criticism:
- There is no criticism in this case.
Action: Answer("A")

  To model the total number of businesses the DBA plans to have as members x years from now, we need to use an exponential growth function.
  A: This is a linear function, not an exponential growth function.
  B: This is a linear function, not an exponential growth function.
  C: This is an exponential function, but it is not in the correct form to model exponential growth over time. It models exponential growth based on repeated multiplication of the same number.
  D: This is an exponential growth function. It models the total number of businesses the DBA plans to have as members x years from now.

  The function must be an exponential growth function.
  The initial number of businesses, b, is included in the function. 
  The function must include an exponent of x, representing the number of years.
  The function must include the rate of growth, n, representing the number of businesses the DBA plans to increase its membership each year.
  The function that satisfies the above requirements is D: $y=n(b)^{x}$

  There is no apparent flaw in the thinking.
